name: Cariboo
desc: The Cariboo economic region is the third largest development region in the province, encompassing 131,286 square kilometres of land in the northern interior of the province. It spans from the Cariboo plateau in the west to the valleys of the Cariboo and Rocky Mountain ranges. It includes the city of Prince George, which acts as a major service centre for the northern half of the province. Just over 6% of the region's 153,800 residents are First Nations. The Cariboo region is characterized by vast forests, rivers, lakes, mountains, and interior plateau lands between the Coast Mountains and the Rockies. The region is comprised of the traditional territories of a number of interior First Nations: The Secwepemc and Stl'atl'imx in the south-central part of the region, the Tsilhqot'in in the region's east, and the Dakelh in the north towards Prince George and beyond.
bgd: Since time immemorial, the inhabitants of the Cariboo region maintained a sustainable socioeconomic system using the rich and varied abundance of natural resources of the region. Fishing in the Cariboo's many rivers and lakes historically played a large economic role, and today recreational and sport fishing remain important, both culturally and economically. In the 1860s, a gold rush descended on the Cariboo region, bringing prospectors from across North America eager to make their fortunes. Other entrepreneurs soon moved to the area to service the growing boomtowns. Today, resource-based industries such as mining and forestry, as well as spin-off support industries like lumber processing and trucking, continue to play a strong role in the area's economy.
sum: With a greater population than its northern neighboring regions (North Coast, Nechako and Northeast), the Cariboo regional economy is comparatively larger in sectors such as health care professional services, administration and manufacturing, while still being based primarily in the natural-resources sector.  The rich forestry and mining resources that formed the basis of the early settler economy continue to play dominant roles, supporting Prince George as a service and supply hub for natural resource and construction activities. The boom-and-bust nature of these industries, impacted by fluctuating commodities prices, as well as natural disturbances like the Pine Beetle infestation, have contributed to a higher degree of economic instability in the region compared to the province's more diverse southern economies. Cariboo's closer proximity to southern British Columbia has enabled growth of the outdoor recreation economy, including fishing, boating, hiking and biking in the summer months and skiing and snowmobiling in the winter.

grp.name: Tsilhqot'in National Government
grp.desc: was established in 1989 to meet the needs of and represent the Tsilhqot'in communities of Tl'etinqox, ?Esdilagh, Yunesit'in, Tsi Deldel, Tl'esqox and Xeni Gwet'in as they strove to re-establish a strong political government structure.

grp.name: Northern Shuswap Tribal Council
grp.desc: a political alliance between four of the 17 bands that are known as the Secwepemc Nation (which spans both the Cariboo and Thompson Okanagan regions). The four bands comprising the NSTC are: the Tsq'escen' (Canim Lake), Stswecem'c/Xgat'tem (Canoe & Dog Creek), Xat'sūll (Soda & Deep Creek), and T'exelc (Williams Lake a.k.a. Sugar Cane).

grp.name: Carrier Chilcotin Tribal Council
grp.desc: a political alliance that seeks to build unity and enhance the wellbeing of four central interior communities (Ulkatcho, Lhtako Dene, Toosey, and Kluskus) and their citizens through the delivery of quality programs and services.

name: Kootenay
desc: The Kootenay region encompasses 57,720 square kilometres of land in the southeast corner of B.C. and is the second smallest region in the province. Largely rural in nature, the region extends from Radium Hot Springs in the north to the US border in the south, and from the city of Greenwood in the west across the Monashee, Selkirk, and Purcell Mountains to the Municipality of Sparwood in the Rocky Mountains to the east. Cranbrook is the largest population and commercial centre in the region. Approximately 1% of the region's 148,300 residents are First Nations. The pristine rivers, lakes, waterfalls, beaches, mineral hot springs, alpine meadows and snow-capped mountains of the Kootenay region are primarily the traditional territory of the Ktunaxa ethnic group, who have inhabited the area (as well as parts of modern-day Montana, Washington and Idaho) since time immemorial. It is the Ktunaxa after whom the region draws its name. The Ktunaxa are linguistically distinct from other First Nations. The western stretches of the Kootenay region are also considered traditional Okanagan and Secwepemc territory.
bgd: The traditional Kootenay economy revolved around seasonal use of the diverse natural resources in the region. The Kootenay River served as a transportation artery and food source, as well as a primary site for many Ktunaxa villages. Like much of the rest of British Columbia, the settler economy brought unprecedented development of the natural resources sector, with timber harvesting becoming the region's first commercial industry in the mid 1800's. Coal was discovered in the late 1800's; mining began before the turn of the 20th century and now, along with the extraction of other minerals, makes up a significant portion of the regional economy. Today, the Kootenay economy also includes tourism and outdoor recreation, with numerous restored heritage towns, as well as vibrant arts and cultural events.
sum: Today, the main pillars of the Kootenay regional economy continue to be tourism, mining, and forestry, with much of regional employment existing directly in, or in support of these three sectors. Coal extraction from multiple mines in the region's Elk Valley— home to the largest coalfields in the province— continues to provide significant employment. A progressive Impact Management Benefits Agreement has been signed between the communities of the Ktunaxa Nation and Teck Resources, a primary mining proponent in the area. Lumber and pulp production continue to be important industries throughout the region. Towards the southern regional boundary, zinc and lead smelting and refining, as well as wood products manufacturing play key roles. A spectrum of all-season recreation, tourism, and cultural activities and amenities throughout the region make tourism a year-round income generator.

grp.name: Ktunaxa Nation
grp.desc: comprised of four individual First Nations communities: ?Akisq'nuk, St. Mary's (ʔaq̓am), Tobacco Plains (ʔakink̓umǂasnuqǂiʔit), and Lower Kootenay (yaqan nuykiy). It seeks to manage Ktunaxa lands and resources, uphold Ktunaxa culture, and improve the lives of its members as a self sufficient, self-governing Nation.

grp.name: Ktunaxa Kinbasket Treaty Council
grp.desc: the Treaty negotiation arm of the Ktunaxa Nation.

grp.name: Shuswap Nation Tribal Council
grp.desc: , also known as SNTC, was formed in 1980 as an effort of the Secwepemc chiefs to advance the issues and aboriginal rights of the following Shuswap First Nations: Adams Lake, Bonaparte, Neskonlith, Shuswap, Simpcw, Skeetchestn, Splatsín, Tk'emlúps, Whispering Pines/Clinton. Only the Shuswap First Nation is located the Kootenay region, with the others located within the Thompson Okanagan and Cariboo Regions.

name: Lower Mainland Southwest
desc: The Mainland Southwest economic region encompasses 36,305 square kilometres of land in the southwest corner of the B.C. mainland. It includes the Greater Vancouver area, the Fraser Valley and the Sunshine Coast, and stretches north to include Whistler, Pemberton and Lillooet. While it is one of British Columbia's smallest regions in terms of land area, it is home to over 60% of the provincial population, and serves as B.C.'s principal economic hub. While the Mainland Southwest has the third highest First Nations population (24,475) of the eight regions, this makes up the smallest percentage, at 0.84% of the region's 2.9 million inhabitants. The region's mountains, oceans, lakes, inlets, beaches, the Fraser River plain and delta, and lands surrounding the Salish Sea (Georgia Strait) make up the traditional territory of the Coast Salish Peoples. The Coast Salish peoples are a vast and diverse network of culturally and linguistically linked individual communities that comprise one of the largest indigenous cultural groups in British Columbia.
bgd: The large pre-European Coast Salish population numbered in the tens of thousands and was organized into sophisticated socio-economic structures, with many distinct communities and linguistic dialects. Communities existed along the Fraser River valley, in the present day city of Vancouver and in the surrounding mountainous mainland north to Bute Inlet. The Coast Salish also inhabited the Gulf Islands, the southern area of Vancouver Island including the City of Victoria and into modern-day United States along the coast of Washington and Oregon. The Fraser River served as a major transportation artery, and its salmon run provided one of the largest single sources of food in the region. The relatively flat and fertile lands of the Fraser delta allowed for plentiful natural crops. The highly habitable and naturally productive capacity of the region supported the large pre-colonial population and economy; it is because of these characteristics that the Mainland Southwest became the colonial economic and population centre as well. Initial economic drivers in the Lower Mainland Southwest were, like much of the rest of the province, initially the fur trade, then forestry and mining. Quickly, trade, finance, and manufacturing sectors emerged to manage and support the new colonial economy, and a rapidly growing population gave rise to service, health, and education sectors throughout the 19th and 20th centuries. The 1990's and 2000's also saw a strong technology sector emerge in the Mainland Southwest.
sum: With Vancouver serving as Canada's primary trade gateway to Asia, the trade and financial services sectors today are dominant parts of the regional economy. Healthcare and social assistance, as well as professional, scientific and technical services, are also dominant sectors in terms of employment numbers. There has also been significant growth in the information, culture, and recreation sector. Transportation, education, secondary manufacturing, and agriculture continue to be core economic pillars. In the area of the mainland that lies directly north of Metro Vancouver, logging and mining continue to play an important role, though proportionally a much smaller one than in other more rural regions of British Columbia.

grp.name: In-SHUCK-ch Nation
grp.desc: comprised of Samahquam and Skatin, two individual First Nations of the larger St'át'imc (Stl'atl'imx) group, which has eleven member First Nations. In-SHUCK-ch Nation is also a member of the Lower Stl'atl'imx Tribal Council.

grp.name: Lower Stl'atl'imx Tribal Council
grp.desc: The Lower Stl'atl'imx Tribal Council represents the following five of the eleven St'at'imc First Nations: Samahquam, Skatin, Xa'xtsa, N'Quatqua, and Lil'wat.

grp.name: St'át'imc Chiefs Council (SCC)
grp.desc: comprised of one Chief from each St'át'imc community. The St'at'imc communities are Bridge River (Xwisten), Pavilion (Ts'kw'aylaxw), Cayoose Creek (Sekw'al'was), Mt. Currie (Lil'wat), Lillooet (T'it'q'et), Fountain (Xaxli'p), Anderson Lake (N'Quatqua), Douglas (Xa'xtsa), Skatin, Samahquam, and Seton (Tsal'alh).

grp.name: Naut'sa mawt Tribal Council
grp.desc: comprised of eleven Coast Salish First Nations: Halalt, Homalco, Klahoose, Malahat, Snaw-Naw-as (Nanoose), Snuneymuxw, Stz'uminus, Tla'amin, Tsawwassen, Tseil-Wau-Tuth, and T'Sou-Ke. Only Tsawwassen and Tseil-Wau-Tuth are located within the Lower Mainland Southwest region.

grp.name: Nlaka'pamux First Nation Tribal Council
grp.desc: comprised of six Nlaka'pamux First Nations: Boothroyd, Boston Bar, Spuzzum, Skuppah, Oregon Jack Creek, and Lytton. Boothroyd, Boston Bar, and Spuzzum are located within the Lower Mainland Southwest, while Spuzzum, Skuppah, and Oregon Jack Creek fall within the Thompson Okanagan region.

grp.name: Stó:lo Nation
grp.desc: the political amalgamation of eleven Stó:lō communities: Aitchelitz, Shxwha:y, Leq' A: Mel, Squiala, Matsqui, Sumas, Popkum, Tzeachten, Skawahlook, Yakweakwioose, and Skowkale.

grp.name: Stó:lo Tribal Council
grp.desc: an Aboriginal organization representing eight villages in the traditional Stolo territory. These villages include Shxw'ow'hamel, Seabird Island, Cheam, Chawathil, KwawKwawApilt, Scowlitz, Soowahlie and Kwantlen.

grp.name: Sto:lo Xwexwilmexw Treaty Association
grp.desc: comprised of seven Sto:lo First Nation Bands who have joined together to negotiate with the federal and provincial governments in the B.C. Treaty Process. These bands include: Aitchelitz, Leq'a:mel, Popkum, Skawahlook, Skowkale, Tzeachten, and Yakweakwioose.

name: Nechako
desc: Located in the northwestern part of the province, Nechako stretches from the B.C.–Yukon border in the north down to the central “Lakes” area of the province and is separated from the northeastern section of the province by the Rocky Mountain Trench. It is separated from the Pacific Ocean by the temperate rainforests of B.C.'s North Coast Region and the coastal “panhandle” of southeastern Alaska. While it is the largest development region, encompassing 194,024 square kilometers of land, it is also the least populated; Nechako is home to under 40,000 residents, more than 30% of whom are First Nations. There are few large population centres in the region, except in the far south along Highway 16 (Smithers, Houston, and Burns Lake). The Nechako region is comprised of the Traditional Territories of the Sekani and Kaska Dene in the north and the Dakelh, Wet'suwet'en further south. The land is generally mountainous, with many large lakes and rivers that have sustained a traditional economy and trade system since time immemorial.
bgd: The Nechako Region has long been a vast and very sparsely populated territory, where numerous Indigenous peoples have, since time immemorial, maintained a sustainable economy that revolves around fishing, hunting, and use of the forests, rivers and immense lakes in the region.
sum: The Region's most densely populated and commercially active areas lie in its southern reaches, located between Prince George and Prince Rupert, with well connected transportation and communication networks. Mining plays a large role in most parts of the Nechako region, with many companies actively exploring for minerals and developing agreements and joint ventures related to mining with First Nations. Agriculture (largely cattle ranching and dairy) plays both a historic and contemporary role in the regional economy. Timber harvesting and lumber production are a very dominant economic force, while a growing outdoor tourism industry is emerging as a result of improved transportation networks allowing access to high quality recreational fishing opportunities, abundant and diverse wildlife, high mountainous terrain for trail development and climbing, swift flowing rivers, and calm lakes. Development corporations— owned collectively by aligned Nations or by individual First Nations— are the primary vehicles by which First Nations pursue and advocate for sustainable economic development, and can be explored through the Community Profiles Section of this database. The vast and sparsely populated northern reaches of the Nechako region are home to under 1000 individuals, but contain numerous mining and forestry operations. Both the northern and southern Nechako region can reach international export opportunities via the deep water port in Prince Rupert.

name: North Coast
desc: The North Coast Region covers the northern coastal areas of the province (north of Bella Bella) as well as Haida Gwaii. Prince Rupert, Terrace and Kitimat are the major population and commercial centres in the region. Over 60% of the Region's 56,200 inhabitants are First Nations, the highest percentage of the 8 BC Development Regions. The North Coast Region is comprised of the Traditional Territories of the Coast Tsimshian along the Skeena River and surrounding its delta; the Haida on Haida Gwaii; the Tlingit along the coast north of Prince Rupert; the Nisga'a along the Nass River Valley and its delta; and the Tahltan along the Stikine River and further inland. The Coastal geography is made up of fruitful oceans, vast temperate coastal rainforests, and deep fjords that quickly give way to drier mountainous climates further inland. The region houses many large rivers including the Nass, Skeena and Stikine. While much of the coastline north of Prince Rupert is considered Alaska, USA, it is historically and geographically linked to the Region.
bgd: Historically, the First Nations inhabiting the North Coast relied heavily on the ocean and rivers for food, transportation and trade. Forest resources were also consumed at a small and highly sustainable scale.
sum: First Nations play a large economic role in the North Coast Region as both project proponents and stakeholders, developing and advocating for socially and environmentally prudent projects with the goal of improving quality of life in the Region. Development Corporations— owned collectively by aligned Nations or by individual First Nations— are the primary vehicles by which First Nations pursue and advocate for Sustainable Economic Development, and can be explored through the Community Profiles Section of this database. With proposed LNG liquefaction and export terminals in the Prince Rupert area numbering in the double-digits, LNG developments pose a large impact on First Nations in the area who are working actively to ensure their communities benefit from future projects. Commercial Fishing, Forestry, and mining continue to make up a large part of the Regional Economy.

grp.name: Nisga'a Lisims Government
grp.desc: administers the Nisga'a Nation, which is comprised of four individual First Nations communities in the Nass River Valley: Gitlaxt'aamiks (New Aiyansh), Gitwinksihlkw, Laxgalts'ap, Gingolx

grp.name: Gitxsan Government Commission
grp.desc: provides administrative support to four First Nations (Gitanyow, Gitanmaax, Glen Vowell and Kispiox) of the Gitxsan people located along the Skeena, Kispiox and Kitwanga Rivers.

grp.name: Coastal First Nations
grp.desc: an alliance of First Nations on British Columbia's North and Central Coast and Haida Gwaii. The Coastal First Nations include Wuikinuxv Nation, Heiltsuk, Kitasoo/Xaixais, Nuxalk Nation, Gitga'at, Metlakatla, Old Massett, Skidegate, and Council of the Haida Nation.

grp.name: Office of the Wet'suwet'en Society
grp.desc: provides Administrative support for five First Nations of the traditional Wet'suwet'en People: Hagwilget, Moricetown, Browman Lake, Skin Tyee, Nee Tahi Buhn. The individual First Nation known to Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada as “Wet'suwet'en” is not a member of the Office of the Wet'suwet'en Society.

grp.name: Tsimshian First Nation Treaty Society
grp.desc: negotiates on behalf of its member Nations, which are some, but not all First Nations of the traditional Tsimshian People. TFN Treaty Society members include Kitselas, Kitsumkalum, Metlakatla, Gitga'at, and Kitasoo.

grp.name: Tahltan Central Government
grp.desc: the political entity that represents the Tahltan People, who are comprised of two First Nations: Tahltan and Iskut First Nations Council of the Haida Nation is the political entity representing the Haida People, who are comprised of two individual First Nations: Old Masset Village Council and Skidegate Village Council.

name: Northeast
desc: The Northeast region encompasses 202,502 square kilometres of land, making up approximately 22% of B.C.'s total land base. The region shares a border with Alberta and the Yukon and is part of the Peace River Basin. It is separated from the northwestern part of the province by the Rocky Mountain Trench. The main population and commercial centres in the region are Fort St. John and Dawson Creek.  Approximately 7% of the region's 68,700 residents are First Nations. With much of the region lying east of the Rockies, the physical geography of the Northeast is distinct from much of the rest of the province: a vast and remote area of foothills, forests, lakes and the Peace River valley.  The eastern region beyond the Rockies is the traditional territory of the Dene Tha' cultural group and further north, the Acho Dene Koe. The mountainous western border of the region is considered traditional Kaska Dena territory.
bgd: The traditional economy of the Dene Tha' and Acho Dene Koe cultural groups was based on a semi-nomadic hunting and gathering society. The less mountainous nature of the terrain east of the Rockies facilitated relatively easy and efficient movement throughout the territory. Being so far north, the colonial economic influence on the region began later than in the south of the province. In the early twentieth century, numerous regional First Nations signed onto Treaty 8 (drafted originally in 1899), which secured access to and protection of the lands upon the traditional economy was built.
sum: Similarly to other vast, sparsely-populated regions in B.C., the contemporary Northeastern economy is based on natural resources, particularly natural gas production and coal mining. As of 2016, there were 62 major projects operational in the area with a combined value of over $3.7 billion, most of which are in the oil, gas and mining sectors. Another important industry is utilities, due to the power demand from industrial activity in the region. There are many power-generating projects in the planning stages; these include the proposed $7.9 billion B.C. Hydro Site C project. The Site C dam is poised to contribute to economic growth in the region, but opponents worry about the significant flooding of Peace River Valley it would entail, among other concerns. Other important industries are rooted in the earlier regional economy and continue to be important economic drivers in the region. These include logging, wood products manufacturing and agriculture.

grp.name: Treaty 8 First Nations
grp.desc: a service delivery organization for six First Nations in northeastern B.C. that are signatories to Treaty 8: Doig River, Halfway River, Prophet River, Saulteau, West Moberly, and Fort Nelson First Nations. It acts as a coordinator and facilitator, providing technical support on various issues as mandated by its member Nations.

grp.name: Kaska Dena Council
grp.desc: was formed to advance the interests of Kaska groups and individuals, primarily in treaty settlement discussions. It is made up of five Kaska communities across northern B.C. and the southern Yukon. B.C. bands include Daylu Dena Council and Dease River First Nation.

name: Thompson Okanagan
desc: The region encompasses 94,199 square kilometres of land, stretching from Princeton and the Cascade Mountains in the west to the Monashee Mountains and the Alberta border in the east; and from the Washington state border in the south up to Mount Robson, the highest peak in the Rocky Mountains in the north. This area is renowned for its sunny climate, beautiful landscapes, and in the south, Canada's only desert terrain. With approximately 545,500 residents, it is the third most populous development region in B.C. after Lower Mainland Southwest and Vancouver Island and Coast. Approximately 3.43% of the Thompson Okanagan regional population are First Nations. The region's moderate climate has, since time immemorial, made it a desirable and fruitful place to live. Its mountains, rivers, large lakes, and fertile valleys comprise the traditional territory of numerous First Nations: towards the region's western border lie the eastern reaches of the Sto:lo territory; in the south central portion of the region lies the traditional territories of the Nlaka'pamux and Okanagan, respectively centred around the Nicola and Okanagan valleys. Further north, towards and beyond Kamloops is traditional Secwepemc territory.
bgd: The original inhabitants of the Thompson Okanagan region relied heavily on its rivers, valleys and mountain passes, which provided “highways” to access the resources that sustained a productive and organized socioeconomic system. Salmon were fished from the rivers and streams, game was hunted in the forests, mountains and grasslands, and plants and medicines were gathered throughout the territory, all the while supporting a robust system of trade, kinship, and governance between neighbouring nations. The large-scale settler economy was preceded by an early fur-trade and homesteading era. The first large period of non-Indigenous economic growth took the form of a large gold rush in the mid-to-late 1800's. This gold rush attracted a number of Europeans, many of whom immigrated north from the United States, creating an unprecedented demand for goods, services, and land. As agriculture expanded in the fertile region, First Nations were forced off their land where the settler economy deemed necessary.
sum: Like the southern districts of the Vancouver Island and Coast region, the Thompson-Okanagan's moderate climate and scenic beauty have attracted both tourism and population inflow, especially by retirees, over many years. This, in turn, has brought pension and investment income to the region and stimulated development, construction, and service sector employment. Today, the region's economy is a diverse mix of industries that is predominantly service-based, although its historic industrial base of forestry, mining, and agriculture remains important. The trade sector as well as the health care and social assistance industry are the development region's top two employers, followed by various forms of manufacturing, accommodation and food services. The region has also become an important centre for post-secondary education.

grp.name: Shuswap Nation Tribal Council
grp.desc: Shuswap Nation Tribal Council, also known as SNTC, was formed in 1980 as an effort of the Secwepemc chiefs to advance the issues and Aboriginal rights of the following Shuswap First Nations: Adams Lake, Bonaparte, Neskonlith, Shuswap, Simpcw, Skeetchestn, Splatsín, Tk'emlúps, Whispering Pines/Clinton. Note: several SNTC bands are located outside the Thompson Okanagan region.

grp.name: Nicola Tribal Association
grp.desc: is an alliance between eight First Nation communities, all located within a 115-kilometre radius of Merritt, British Columbia, in the Nicola Valley, along the Thompson River, and Fraser Canyon. The NTA Membership Communities are: Nooaitch, Shackan, Coldwater, Siska, Nicomen, Cook's Ferry, Upper Nicola, and Lower Nicola.

grp.name: Okanagan Nation Alliance (ONA)
grp.desc: was formed in 1981 as the inaugural First Nations government in the Okanagan. It represents the eight member communities including: Okanagan Indian Band, Upper Nicola Band, Westbank First Nation, Penticton Indian Band, Osoyoos Indian Band and Lower and Upper Similkameen Indian Bands and the Colville Confederated Tribes.

grp.name: Nlaka'pamux First Nation Tribal Council
grp.desc: comprised of six Nlaka'pamux First Nations: Boothroyd, Boston Bar, Spuzzum, Skuppah, Oregon Jack Creek, and Lytton. Boothroyd, Boston Bar, and Spuzzum are located within the Lower Mainland Southwest region, while Spuzzum, Skuppah, and Oregon Jack Creek fall within the Thompson Okanagan region.

name: Vancouver Island & Coast
desc: 759,400 The Vancouver Island and Coast region encompasses 84,231 square kilometres of land on Vancouver Island, the Gulf Islands, and the central portion of B.C.'s mainland coast from Powell River to just north of Ocean Falls and Bella Coola. This region is known for its temperate climate, unspoiled wilderness and beautiful coastlines. In 2015, the region was home to 793,800 residents, making it the second-most-populated region in B.C. after Lower Mainland Southwest. Nearly half the region's residents reside in Victoria's Capital Regional District, 20% in Nanaimo and another 22% principally in small to medium sized communities in the mid and southeast coast of Vancouver Island. The rest of the region is sparsely populated and largely undeveloped. Many communities in these sparsely populated regions in the northern half of Vancouver Island and the mainland portion of the region are First Nations communities. Approximately 5% (39,300) of the regional population are First Nations. This is the highest absolute First Nations population of any region, although other regions have higher proportional First Nations populations, such as the North Coast, whose 35,300 First Nations residents make up over 60% of the total regional population. The geographically diverse Vancouver Island and Coast region contains mountains, fertile agricultural lands, beaches, ancient rainforests, rivers, fjords, and archipelagos, which make up the traditional territory of many Coast Salish groups:  Heiltsuk, Nuxalk, Wuikinuxv, Gwa'sala-‘Nakwaxda'xw, and Da'naxda'xw in the northern mainland portion of the region adjacent to Queen Charlotte Sound; Quatsino, Nuu-chah-nulth, and Kwakwak'awakw on north and central Vancouver Island; Ditidaht, Pacheedaht, Saanich, Beecher Bay [Scia'new], Malahat, Nanoose [Snaw-naw-as], Songhees, Sooke [T'sou-ke], and Hul'qumi'num on southern Vancouver Island.
bgd: Most First Nations in the Vancouver Island and Coast region are linguistically and culturally linked to groups in the Lower Mainland Southwest region — a result of the high levels of movement of people, goods, and knowledge throughout pre-colonial Salishian economy. The regional economic history is similar to that of the Lower Mainland Southwest region: the naturally bountiful Vancouver Island and Coast region, which supported large Indigenous populations, was the ideal location for settler colonial development. In tandem with the Lower Mainland Southwest, the forestry economy grew, as did the population— especially in the new British Columbian capital, Victoria.
sum: Today, the service sector is the region's primary employer. Population growth— especially from retirees— attracted by the moderate climate, and tourism activity are the region's primary economic drivers. These drivers generate investment, construction activity, and demand for services. Public administration is also a major employer and economic catalyst in Victoria. An emerging technology sector is providing increasing employment in southern Vancouver Island, with high real estate prices in Vancouver reportedly driving talent to Victoria. The contemporary economy of the mid and north Island and mainland coast is more akin to other, more rural economic regions in BC, with commercial fishing and logging continuing to play a large role in providing local employment. First Nations communities in these regions are economically active in these traditional natural resource sectors, as well as in the tourism and ecotourism industries, which seek to conserve, protect, and showcase the astounding ecological value of the region.

grp.name: Nuu-chah-nulth Tribal Council (NTC)
grp.desc: a not-for-profit society that provides a wide variety of services and supports to fourteen Nuu-chah-nulth First Nations with approximately 10,000 members. The 14 Nuu-chah-nulth First Nations are divided into three regions. Southern Region: Ditidaht, Huu-ay-aht, Hupacasath, Tse-shaht, and Uchucklesaht. Central Region: Ahousaht, Hesquiaht, Tla-o-qui-aht, Toquaht, and Yuu-cluth-aht. Northern Region: Ehattesaht, Kyuquot/Cheklesaht, Mowachat/Muchalaht, and Nuchatlaht.

grp.name: Te'mexw Treaty Association
grp.desc: a non-profit society formed of five Coast Salish First Nations: Songhees, Nanoose (Snaw-Naw-As), Beecher Bay (Scia'new), T'Sou-ke and Malahat. The five Te'mexw Member First Nations joined together with one common objective; to support one another and to work together as a single organization to negotiate a modern treaty with the federal and provincial government in the British Columbia Treaty Process.

grp.name: Laich-Kwil-Tach Treaty Society
grp.desc: the body that acts on behalf of the We Wai Kum Nation, We Wai Kai Nation, and Kwiakah First Nations in negotiating a modern treaty with the federal and provincial governments.

grp.name: Hul'qumi'num Treaty Group
grp.desc: represents six communities: Chemainus, Cowichan Tribes, Halalt, Lake Cowichan, Lyackson and Penelakut. The First Nation traditionally occupied and used the area around Duncan, north to Ladysmith, east to the Gulf Islands and west to Cowichan Lake.

grp.name: Kwakiutl District Council
grp.desc: a political organization representing 9 of the 15 bands of the Kwakwak'awakw (Kwak'wala speaking peoples): Mamalilikulla Qwe'Qwa' Sot'Em Nation, Da'naxda'xw Nation, Gwa'sala-‘Nakwaxda'xw Nation, Kwakiutl Nation, Tlatlasikwala Nation, Cape Mudge Nation, Campbell River Nation, Kwiakah First Nation, and K'ómoks First Nation.

grp.name: Musgamagw Dzawada'enuxw Tribal Council
grp.desc: a longstanding traditional alliance between four tribes: Gwawa'enuxw (Hopetown), Kwickwasut'inuxw  (Gilford), Haxwa'mis (Wakeman) and Dzawada'enuxw (Kingcome). MDTC provides resources, support and representation for its member communities.

grp.name: Naut'sa mawt Tribal Council
grp.desc: comprised of eleven Coast Salish First Nations: Halalt, Homalco, Klahoose, Malahat, Snaw-Naw-as (Nanoose), Snuneymuxw, Stz'uminus, Tla'amin, Tsawwassen, Tseil-Wau-Tuth, and T'Sou-Ke. Tsawwassen and Tseil-Wau-Tuth are located within the Lower Mainland Southwest region, outside the Vancouver Island and Coast region.

grp.name: Maa-nulth First Nations
grp.desc: an alliance between the Huu-ay-aht, Ka:'yu:'k't'h'/Chek'tles7et'h', Toquaht, Uchucklesaht, and Ucluelet First Nations, which finalized the negotiation of a modern treaty in 2011 with the federal and provincial governments through the B.C. Treaty Process.

grp.name: Coastal First Nations
grp.desc: a community economic development organization and an alliance serving the Wuikinuxw, Kitasoo, and Nuxalk First Nations. The role of WKNTC is to provide advisory and/or program services to band members in the areas of community planning, band government, technical services, financial management and economic development.

grp.name: Nanwakolas Council
grp.desc: comprised of First Nations belong to the Kwakwaka'wakw – a culturally defined group of First Nations sharing the same language, Kwakʼwala and Lik'wala, located on northern Vancouver Island and the adjacent southern Central Coast area, including the many islands in between. Its member First Nations include Mamalilikulla, Tlowitsis, Da'naxda'xw Awaetlatla, Wei Wai Kum, Kwiakah and K'ómoks.
